results.title: Middle East Crisis: Israeli Military Warns More Than 100,000 People in Rafah to Evacuate
results.abstract: Israel wants to “move people out of harm’s way,” a military official said, a sign that it may be inching closer to invading the Gazan city in defiance of international pressure.

results.title: With Schools in Ruins, Education in Gaza Will Be Hobbled for Years
results.abstract: Most of Gaza’s schools, including all of its universities, have severe damage that makes them unusable, which could harm an entire generation, the United Nations and others say.
results.byline: By Liam Stack and Bilal Shbair

multimedia.caption: Palestinian children last month at a destroyed school in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip. More than 80 percent of Gaza’s schools have been severely damaged or destroyed by fighting, according to the United Nations.

Palestinian children last month at a destroyed school in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip. More than 80 percent of Gaza’s schools have been severely damaged or destroyed by fighting, according to the United Nations.

results.title: In Meeting With Xi, E.U. Leader Takes Tough Line on Ukraine War
results.abstract: Ursula Von der Leyen, the European Commission president, pushed Beijing to help rein in Russia’s war in Ukraine after meeting with the Chinese and French leaders in Paris.

multimedia.caption: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen after a meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Xi Jinping of China at Elysee Palace.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen after a meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Xi Jinping of China at Elysee Palace.

results.title: Meet the Candidate Challenging Venezuela’s Authoritarian President
results.abstract: Edmundo González, a former diplomat, is unknown to many Venezuelans. But some experts say that could work in his favor as he runs against President Nicolás Maduro in national elections.
results.byline: By Genevieve Glatsky, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez

multimedia.caption: Edmundo González has emerged as the candidate the government would not seek to block and that the opposition would support.

results.abstract: Russian officials claimed the order was in response to comments from the West about the possibility of more direct Western involvement in the war in Ukraine.

results.title: What to Know About Xi Jinping’s Trip to Europe
results.abstract: The Chinese president this week will be visiting France, Serbia and Hungary. His trip comes at a time of tensions with many European countries over trade and accusations of Chinese espionage.

results.title: Xi Visits Europe, Seeking Strategic Opportunity
results.abstract: The Chinese leader has carefully chosen three countries — France, Serbia and Hungary — that to varying degrees embrace Beijing’s push for a new global order.
results.byline: By Roger Cohen and Chris Buckley

multimedia.caption: President Xi Jinping of China and his wife, Peng Liyuan, on Sunday at Orly airport, south of Paris. Mr. Xi’s visit to Europe is testing the continent’s delicate balancing act between China and the United States.

results.abstract: Mr. Mulino, a former security minister, gained support in the chaotic campaign from an ex-president whose bid had been disqualified.

results.title: His Skull Was Taken From Congo as a War Trophy. Will Belgium Finally Return It?
results.abstract: For decades, Belgium failed to return the remains of hundreds of people taken by force from former colonies. A draft law could change that, but critics say it is not going far enough.
results.byline: By Monika Pronczuk and Koba Ryckewaert
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Belgian Royal Museum for Central Africa

multimedia.caption: The skull of a Congolese leader, Lusinga Iwa Ng’ombe, who fought back against Belgian colonial invaders in the late 19th century, ended up in a box at the Institute for Natural Sciences in Brussels, along with over 500 human remains taken from former Belgian colonies.

The skull of a Congolese leader, Lusinga Iwa Ng’ombe, who fought back against Belgian colonial invaders in the late 19th century, ended up in a box at the Institute for Natural Sciences in Brussels, along with over 500 human remains taken from former Belgian colonies.

results.title: Just How Dangerous Is Europe’s Rising Far Right?
results.abstract: Anti-immigration parties with fascist roots — and an uncertain commitment to democracy — are now mainstream.

results.title: Rishi Sunak’s Dismal Task: Leading U.K. Conservatives to Likely Defeat
results.abstract: After 14 years of Conservative government, Britain’s voters appear hungry for change. And Prime Minister Rishi Sunak seems unable to persuade them otherwise.

results.title: Cease-Fire Talks Between Israel and Hamas Again at an Impasse
results.abstract: There had been signs the two sides were inching closer to an agreement, but talks in Cairo stalled and a Hamas delegation left the city.

results.title: The Bleak Life of a Deposed President and His Wife, Held Captive
results.abstract: Nine months after a coup in Niger, Mohamed Bazoum, an ally of France and the U.S., remains locked in the presidential residence, cut off from contact with anyone but his doctor.
